title: How to Shoot Macro With a Compact Digital Camera

steps.headline: Find where the macro icon is on your camera and set your camera to it.
steps.description: It is easy to find; all cameras use a flower icon to indicate the macro setting.

steps.headline: Use a tripod.
steps.description: You will have a reduced depth of field and the tripod will help keep your images sharp.

steps.headline: See if you can adjust the aperture.
steps.description: While most point and shoot cameras won't have that option, you won't know until you look. This can help increase or decrease what is in focus.

steps.headline: Be sure that you have a good focus.
steps.description: You might have to move closer or step away from your subject matter.

steps.headline: Know the basic 'rules' of composition.
steps.description: You need to learn the rules before breaking them.

steps.headline: Know what your flash and lighting options are.
steps.description: Be prepared to use extra lighting from your windows, the sun and other light sources.

steps.headline: Take the shot.
steps.description: You won't know if what you are doing will work until you take the shot. Look at it and make adjustments.

steps.headline: See if your model of camera has macro attachments.
Check DIY groups for creating your own attachments and tripods.
steps.description: There are entire DIY communities out there.
